document.docTitle: Molecular phylogeny and morphological characterization of Paramicrothyrium bambusae sp. nov. and Tumidispora thailandica sp. nov. from leaf litter

emphasis.docTitle:
Molecular phylogeny and morphological characterization of
Paramicrothyrium bambusae sp. nov.
and
Tumidispora thailandica sp. nov.
from leaf litter

subSection.paragraph:
DANUSHKA S . TENNAKOON
1,2 , SINANG HONGSANAN 2,3,4 , NIMALI I. DE SILVA 1,2 , NAKARIN SUWANNARACH 1,2 & SAISAMORN LUMYONG 1,2,5 *

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand
Research Center of Microbial Diversity and Sustainable Utilization, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai 50200, Thailand
Department of Entomology and Plant Pathology, Faculty of Agriculture, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai , 50200, Thailand

Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory for Plant Epigenetics, Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Microbial Genetic Engineering, College of Life Science and Oceanography, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, People’s Republic of China
Academy of Science, The Royal Society of Thailand , Bangkok 10300, Thailand

subSection.paragraph: Ễ danushkasandaruwanatm@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2306-1255
Ễ sinang333@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0550-3152
Ễ nimalindeewari@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1577-280X
Ễ suwan.462@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2653-1913
Ễ scboi009@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6485-414X
*Corresponding author: Ễ scboi009@gmail.com

During our ongoing studies of fungal diversity on leaf litter, two exciting species were collected from Thailand . Morphological examination coupled with phylogenetic analyses revealed that our species belongs to
Paramicrothyrium
and
Tumidispora
in
Microthyriaceae
. Maximum likelihood, maximum parsimony, and Bayesian analyses of combined internal transcribed spacer (ITS) and large nuclear subunit ribosomal DNA ( LSU ) sequence data were performed to clarify the phylogenetic affinities of the species. Based on their distinctive morphological traits and phylogenetic support, the new species
Paramicrothyrium bambusae
and
Tumidispora thailandica
were introduced. In addition, the new species were compared with phylogenetically and morphologically closely related species, and detailed descriptions, micrographs, and phylogenetic trees of the new species are provided.

Keywords : 2 new species,
Bambusa vulgaris
,
Dimocarpus longan
, epiphytes,
Microthyriales
, new taxa, taxonomy, Thailand

Fungal foliar epiphytes are an enthralling group of species that mainly occur on the surface of plant leaves (
Wu et al . 2011
,
Hyde et al . 2013
,
Hongsanan et al . 2016
,
Chethana et al . 2021
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022a
, b). They are polyphyletic and ubiquitous, and most belong to Ascomycetes (
Chomnunti et al . 2011
,
Hongsanan et al . 2016
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022a
). Foliar epiphytes occur as black mildews, black dots, and sooty molds which belong to
Asterinales
,
Capnodiales
,
Microthyriales
, Parmulariales , and
Zeloasperisporiales
in
Dothideomycetes
,
Eurotiomycetes , Lecanoromycetes
, and
Meliolales
in
Sordariomycetes
(
Crous et al . 2009
,
Hyde et al . 2013
,
Chomnunti et al . 2011
, 2014,
Hongsanan et al . 2016
,
Chethana et al . 2021
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022b
). The nutritional modes of foliar epiphytes vary and include saprobes, plant parasites, fungal parasites, and lichens ( Carroll 1991 , Gilbert & Reynolds 2002 , 2005 ,
Hongsanan et al . 2016
,
Chethana et al . 2021
). However, most foliar epiphytes are obligate parasites that can harm host plants by invading host cells for nutrition intake (
Wu et al . 2011
,
Chethana et al . 2021
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022b
). In some species, the covering of hyphae on the surface of the plant might cause marketability issues (
Chomnunti et al . 2014
,
Hyde et al . 2018
). Even though the taxonomic history of foliar epiphytes is vast and has been studied extensively for decades, there are still countless unidentified species ( Dickinson & Preece 1976 , Blakeman 1981 , Fokkema & van den Heuvel 1986 , Carroll 1991 ,
Wu et al . 2011
,
Hyde et al . 2013
,
Chomnunti et al . 2014
,
Hongsanan et al . 2014
, 2017 ,
Marasinghe et al . 2022b
). In addition, there are still many taxonomic ambiguities in foliar epiphytes because many species have been identified solely by their morphological characteristics ( Ryan1924 , Luttrell 1973 , von Arx & M̧ller 1975, Barr 1987 ). Therefore, DNA-based molecular phylogeny can be used to address these taxonomic issues of foliar epiphytes. However, the majority of foliar epiphytic species are still lacking DNA molecular data in public databases because most are obligate parasites and difficult to culture in artificial media ( i . e ., PDA , MEA) (
Chomnunti et al . 2014
,
Marasinghe et al . 2022b
).

Microthyriales
contain foliar epiphytes, which was established by Arnaud in (1918) to place
Microthyriaceae
. The species are mostly biotrophs and saprotrophs, usually found on leaves, stems, or fruits (
Hongsanan et al . 2014
,
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). Based on morphology coupled with phylogeny, this order currently contains the single family
Microthyriaceae
(
Hongsanan et al . 2020
,
Wijayawardene et al . 2022
). With the sexual genus
Microthyrium
providing as the type genus, Saccardo (1883) established the
Microthyriaceae
. This family members have superficial, flattened thyriothecia, parallelly arranged upper wall cells, central ostiole, poorly developed lower peridium, obclavate to cylindrical-clavate asci, and hyaline to brown ascospores (
Wu et al . 2011
,
Hyde et al . 2013
,
Hongsanan et al . 2014
,
Qiao et al . 2021
).
Hongsanan et al . (2020)
accepted 11 genera in
Microthyriaceae
(three asexual genera and eight sexual genera). Recently, five additional genera (Asexual morphs) have been introduced to
Microthyriaceae
, such as
Antidactylaria ,
Isthmomyces (
Qiao et al . 2021
)
,
Nothoanungitopsis (
Crous et al . 2021
)
and
Keqinzhangia
,
Pseudocoronospora (
Zheng et al . 2022
)
. Thus, 16 genera are accepted in
Microthyriaceae
, viz .
Antidactylaria
,
Arnaudiella
,
Calothyriopsis
,
Chaetothyriothecium
,
Hamatispora
,
Isthmomyces
,
Keqinzhangia
,
Microthyrium
,
Neoanungitea
,
Nothoanungitopsis
,
Paramicrothyrium
,
Pseudocoronospora
,
Pseudomicrothyrium
,
Pseudopenidiella
,
Seynesiella
, and
Tumidispora
(
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). Among these,
Microthyrium
is the most diverse genus (91 species), and other genera have less than five species, such as
Calothyriopsis
(4),
Chaetothyriothecium
(1),
Hamatispora
(1),
Keqinzhangia
(1),
Neoanungitea
(2),
Paramicrothyrium
(1),
Pseudocoronospora
(1),
Pseudomicrothyrium
(1),
Pseudopenidiella
(3),
Seynesiella
(5), and
Tumidispora
(1) (
Hongsanan et al . 2020
,
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
).

Two intriguing fungal species were collected from Thailand as part of our ongoing research on the diversity of fungi on litter substrates in the tropics. Their taxonomic positions were established through morphological descriptions combined with phylogenetic analyses.

heading.emphasis: Samples collection, morphological studies and isolation

subSection.paragraph:
Leaf litter samples (
Bambusa vulgaris
and
Dimocarpus longan
) were collected from Chiang Mai province , Thailand . All the collected samples were taken back to the university and examined with a stereo-microscope (AXIOSKOP 2 PLUS Series). Squash mount preparations were prepared to determine fungal microscopic features (e.g., asci, ascospores, conidia, and pseudoparaphyses). All the images were captured by using an OLYMPUS SZ61 compound microscope equipped with a Canon AXIO-CAM 506 COLOR digital camera. Lactoglycerol and nail polish were used to prepare the permanent slides. All the photo plates were prepared using Adobe Photoshop CS3 Extended version 10.0 software (Adobe Systems, USA ) and measurements were taken using ZEN2 (blue edition).

The isolation process described by
Senanayake et al . (2020)
was used for single spore isolation. Potato dextrose agar ( PDA ) was used to transfer germinated spores, which were then incubated at 25 ° C . Following that, careful subculturing was carried out to obtain pure cultures. After four weeks of time duration, culture characteristics (on PDA ) were observed. All the type specimens were deposited in the herbariums of Mae Fah Luang University ( MFLU ) and National Chiayi University ( NCYU ). Living cultures were deposited in the Culture Collection of Sustainable Development of Biological Resources Laboratory (SDBR), Faculty of Science, Chiang Mai University. Numbers for Faces of Fungi and Index Fungorum were obtained as described in
Jayasiri et al . (2015)
and Index Fungorum (2022) .

The thermal cycle program for LSU and ITS genes amplification was as follows; initially 95 ° C for 3 mins, followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 95 ° C for 30 secs, annealing at 55 ° C for 50 secs, elongation at 72 ° C for 30 sec and final extension at 72 ° C for 10 mins. Agarose gel electrophoresis (1%) stained with ethidium bromide was used to check the quality of PCR products. PCR products were purified and sequenced by Shanghai Sangon Biological Engineering Technology & Services Co., Ltd, China . Nucleotide sequences were deposited in GenBank ( TABLE 1 ).

caption.paragraph: TABLE 1. GenBank and culture collection accession numbers of species included in this phylogenetic study. The newly generated sequences are shown in bold.

subSection.paragraph:
A combined data set of LSU and ITS genes and a total of 45 isolates were used for the phylogenetic analyses. The newly attained sequences were initially subjected to BLASTn searches in GenBank (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) to identify the taxa that shared the most similarities with our strains. The additional sequences included in the analysis were from recent publications (
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). The
Kirschsteiniothelia lignicola
( MFLUCC 10-0036) was selected as the out-group taxon. Both forward and reverse sequences were assembled using SeqMan v. 7.0.0 (DNASTAR, Madison, WI). Single-gene datasets and multi-gene datasets were aligned with MAFFT ( Katoh & Standley 2013 , http://mafft.cbrc.jp/alignment/server/;2016) and manually improved with BioEdit v.7.2.5 ( Hall 2004 ). The CIPRES Science Gateway platform (
Miller et al . 2010
) was used to create the maximum likelihood tree using the GTR+I+G model of evolution and RAxML-HPC2 on XSEDE (8.2.8) (
Stamatakis et al . 2008
, Stamatakis, 2014 ). PAUP (Phylogenetic Analysis Using Parsimony) version 4.0b10 was used for Maximum parsimony analysis ( MP ) ( Swofford 2002 ). Tree Length (TL), Consistency Index (CI), Retention Index (RI), Relative Consistency Index (RC) and Homoplasy Index (HI) were calculated (Parsimony descriptive tree statistics). MrModeltest v.3.7 (
Posada et al . 1998
) was carried out to check the evolutionary models for phylogenetic analyses under the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC). MrBayes v. 3.1.2 (Huelsenbeck and Ronqvist, 2001) was used for Bayesian analysis (Rannala and Yang, 1996, Zhaxybayeva and Gogarten, 2002). Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method was used to estimate the posterior probability, Markov chains were run for 3,000,000 generations (standard deviation of split frequencies less than 0.01) and trees were sampled every 100 th generation (printfreq=100). In total, 30, 000 trees were resulted and the first 20% of trees were discarded (burn-in phase of the analyses), while the remaining 80% of trees were used for calculating posterior probabilities in the majority rule consensus tree. The FigTree v1.4.0 ( Rambaut, 2012 ) program was used to view the phylogeny trees and reorganized by using Microsoft PowerPoint (2010). Sequences derived in this study were deposited in GenBank ( TABLE 1 ).

The combined data set of LSUs and ITS sequences contained 2001 characters, of which 809 characters are constant, 899 characters are parsimony-informative, while 293 variable characters are parsimony-uninformative in the maximum parsimony ( MP ) analysis (TL = 5235, CI = 0.436, RI = 0.571, RC = 0.249, HI = 0.564). The RAxML analysis of the combined dataset yielded a best-scoring tree ( FIGURE 1 ) with a final ML optimization likelihood value of - 23613.540071. The matrix had 1362 distinct alignment patterns, with 38.76% of undetermined characters or gaps. Estimated base frequencies; A = 0.259082, C = 0.223873, G = 0.296879, T = 0.220166; substitution rates AC = 0.996332, AG = 1.803468, AT = 1.641793, CG = 0.949204, CT = 3.840249, GT = 1.000; proportion of invariable sites I = 0.243698; gamma distribution shape parameter α = 0.701633. The Bayesian analysis resulted in 10000 trees after 1,000,000 generations. All analyses ( ML , MP and BYPP ) gave similar results and were in agreement with previous studies based on multi-gene analyses (
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
).

Combined gene phylogeny showed considerably high bootstrap support within clades ( FIGURE 1 ). Bootstrap support values for ML , MP (≥70%) and BYPP (≥0.95) are given above each branch respectively ( FIGURE 1 ).
Paramicrothyrium bambusae
isolates( MFLU 19-2729and NCYU 19-0085) clustered with the type of
Paramicrothyrium
(
P . chinensis
) isolates ( IFRDCC 2258 and IA 20) with strong statistical support (100% ML , 99% MP , 1.00 BYPP ). In addition,
Paramicrothyrium bambusae
isolates grouped with 100% ML , 99% MP , and 1.00 BYPP support.
Tumidispora thailandica
isolates ( MFLU 19-2771 and NCYU 19-0090) grouped with the type of
Tumidispora
(
T . shoreae
) isolates ( MFLUCC 12-0409 and MFLUCC 14-0574) with high bootstrap support (100% ML , 100% MP , 1.00 BYPP , FIGURE 1 ) and grouped with each other with 100% ML , 99% MP , 1.00 BYPP support ( FIGURE 1 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Phylogram generated from maximum likelihood analysis is based on combined LSU and ITS sequence data. The tree is rooted with
Kirschsteiniothelia lignicola
(MFLUCC 10-0036). The ex-type strains are indicated in bold and the new isolates are indicated in red. Bootstrap support values ≥70% from the maximum likelihood (ML), maximum parsimony (MP) and Bayesian posterior probabilities (BYPP) values ≥0.95 are given above the nodes, respectively.

taxonomicName.authority: H. X. Wu & K. D. Hyde

subSubSection.paragraph:
Wu et al . (2011)
established this as a monotypic genus to include
Paramicrothyrium chinensis
, which has irregular ostioles without a darkened ring. Currently, only the type is available in
Paramicrothyrium ( Index Fungorum 2022 )
. In this study, we introduce
Paramicrothyrium bambusae sp. nov.
from dead leaves of
Bambusa vulgaris
.

paragraph.heading:
Paramicrothyrium bambusae Tennakoon, S. Hongsanan & S. Lumyong
sp . nov .
(
FIGURE 2
)

subSubSection.paragraph: Index Fungorum Number : IF559725; Facesoffungi number : FoF11795

Etymology :—Name reflects the host genus
Bambusa
.

Epiphytic on the upper surface of dead leaves of
Bambusa vulgaris Schrad.
(
Poaceae
), visible as small black dots. Sexual morph : Undetermined. Asexual morph : Thyriothecia 90–120 × 100–130 μm ( x = 110 × 112 µm, n = 10), solitary, scattered, superficial, flattened, circular, dark brown to black, easily be removed from the substrate, poorly developed basal layer, with irregular, central ostiole, dark brown, irregularly rounded at the margin. Upper wall comprises brown cells of textura angularis , radiating in irregular, parallel lines from center to the outer rim. Conidiogenous cells evanescent.
Conidia
3–4 × 1–2 µm ( x = 3.7 × 1.2 μm, n = 30), hyaline, cylindrical with obtuse ends, unicellular, minute guttulate, straight or slightly curved, smooth-walled.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2 .
Paramicrothyrium bambusae
(MFLU 19-2729, holotype ). a, b Thyriothecia on the surface of the leaf (yellow arrows). c Close-up of Thyriothecium. d, e Thyriothecia when, viewed in squash mount. f The upper wall of thyriothecium, when viewed in squash mount. g–i Conidia . j The upper view of colony. k The lower view of colony. Scale bars: d, e = 50 μm, f = 20 μm, g–i = 3 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Culture characteristics :— Colonies on PDA, 10–12 mm diam. after 4 weeks at 25 °C, colonies from above: medium dense, circular, raised, cottony, surface smooth, entire margin, white to cream at margin, white at center; reverse: white to yellowish at margin, light brown at center.
Mycelium
white to cream with tufting.
GenBank numbers :—MFLU 19-2729: ITS: ON751741 ; NCYU 19-0085: ITS: ON751742 .

Notes :—The phylogeny indicates that
Paramicrothyrium bambusae
(MFLU 19-2729 and NCYU 19-0085) forms a distinct lineage sister to
P . chinensis
isolates (IFRDCC2258 and IA20) with robust statistical support (100% ML, 99% MP, 1.00 BYPP, FIGURE 1 ). The morphology of
P . bambusae
fits well with the type species in having circular, dark brown to black thyriothecia with an irregular ostiole, without a darkened ring (
Wu et al . 2011
). However, we were unable to compare
P . chinensis
to the asexual morph of
P . bambusae
, since only the sexual morph was available for that species (
Wu et al . 2011
). Therefore, we compared the base pair differences between
P . bambusae
and
P . chinensis
and there were 25 base pair differences (4.14%) across 603 nucleotides across the ITS (+ 5.8S ) gene region. In addition,
P . bambusae
has smaller thyriothecia (90–120 × 100–130 μm), whereas
P . chinensis
has significantly larger thyriothecia (420–590 μm diam.) (
Wu et al . 2011
). However, further collections are needed to clarify the sexual and asexual connection of
Paramicrothyrium species.

Ariyawansa et al . (2015)
introduced
Tumidispora
to include the generic type
T . shoreae
, which was isolated from
Shorea species
in Thailand .
Tumidispora
has brown to dark brown thyriothecia, with a prominent darkened area around the central ostiole, fissitunicate, cylindrical to cylindric-clavate, short pedicellate asci and 1–2-seriate, hyaline, 1-septate ascospores (constricted at the septum) with an apical swollen cell (
Ariyawansa et al . 2015
). There is currently only the type species in this genus ( Index Fungorum 2022 ). In this study, we introduce
T . thailandica
sp . nov .
from
Dimocarpus longan
in Thailand .

paragraph.heading:
Tumidispora thailandica Tennakoon, S. Hongsanan & S. Lumyong
sp . nov .
(
FIGURE 3
)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3 .
Tumidispora thailandica
(MFLU 19-2771, holotype ). a, b Thyriothecia on the surface of leaf. c Close-up of Thyriothecia. d Thyriothecium when viewed in squash mount. e The upper wall of thyriothecium when viewed in squash mount. f Pseudoparaphyses. g–j Asci. k–o Ascospores (yellow arrows show appendages in upper cells). p A germinating ascospore. q The upper view of colony. r The lower view of colony. Scale bars: d = 100 μm, e = 50 μm, f–j = 20 μm, k–p = 5 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Index Fungorum Number : IF559726; Facesoffungi number : FoF11796

Etymology :—The specific epithet “
thailandica
” refer to the country in which the fungus was first collected

Epiphytic on the upper surface of dead leaves of
Dimocarpus longan Lour.
(
Sapindaceae
), visible as small black dots. Superficial hyphae absent. Sexual morph : Thyriothecia 200–260 × 210–280 μm ( x = 230 × 240 µm, n = 10), solitary, superficial, scattered, flattened, circular, brown to black, easily be removed from the substrate, poorly developed basal layer, with prominent, darker, central ostiole, darker around the ostiole, dark brown towards the outer lighter rim, irregularly rounded at the margin. Upper wall containing brown cells of textura angularis , radiating in slightly irregular, parallel lines from center to the outer rim. Hamathecium containing 2 μm wide, branched pseudoparaphyses. Asci 40–46 × 5–7 μm ( x = 45 × 6 µm, n = 20), 8-spored, fissitunicate, bitunicate, short pedicellate, cylindrical to cylindric-clavate, apically rounded, with an ocular chamber. Ascospores 9–11 × 3–4 μm ( x = 10.5 × 3.5 µm, n = 10), 1–2-seriate, hyaline, fusiform, rounded ends, 1-septate, constricted at the septum, apical cell swollen and wider, basal cell sub-conical, guttulate, two appendages in upper cell, smooth-walled. Asexual morph : Undetermined.

Culture characteristics :— Colonies on PDA, 18–22 mm diam. after 4 weeks at 25 °C, colonies from above: medium dense, circular, raised, surface smooth, entire margin, light green at margin, dark grey to brown at centre; reverse: light brown to light green at margin, dark grey to black at centre.
Mycelium
dark grey to black with tufting.
GenBank numbers :—MFLU 19-2771: LSU: ON751750 ; ITS: ON751739 ; NCYU 19-0090: LSU: ON751751 ; ITS: ON751740 .

Notes:—The morphological characteristics of our collection (MFLU 19-2771 and NCYU 19-0090) tally well with the generic concept of
Tumidispora
, by having flattened, circular, brown to black thyriothecia, cylindrical to cylindricclavate, short pedicellate asci and 1-septate, hyaline ascospores with a swollen apical cell (
Ariyawansa et al . 2015
). But our collection can be distinguished from the type (
T . shoreae
) in having shorter asci (40–46 × 5–7 μm vs 53–55 × 7–8 μm) and ascospores (9–11 × 3–4 μm vs 14–15 × 4–5 μm). In addition, our collection ascospores are distinctly fusiform with rounded ends and consist of two appendages in the upper cell, whereas
T . shoreae
has narrowly fusiform ascospores with sub-papillate ends and lacking appendages (
Ariyawansa et al. 2015
). Phylogeny results show that our collection (MFLU 19-2771 and NCYU 19-0090) forms an independent lineage sister to
T . shoreae
isolates (MFLUCC 12-0409 and MFLUCC 14-0574) with strong statistical support (100% ML, 100% MP, 1.00 BYPP, FIGURE 1 ). Thus, we introduce our collection (MFLU 19-2771 and NCYU 19-0090) as a new species,
T . thailandica
from the dead leaves of
Dimocarpus longan
in Thailand .

subSection.paragraph:
In recent years, there have been several revisions made to the taxonomy of the
Microthyriaceae
. Initially, Saccardo (1883) established this family to accommodate nine genera and was solely based on morphological characteristics, such as flattened, superficial thyriothecia, parallel arrangement of upper wall cells, obclavate to cylindrical-clavate, bitunicate asci and uni- to multi-septate, hyaline to brown ascospores. Subsequently, this family was placed in various orders, viz . Hemisphaeriales ( Theissen 1913 , Luttrell 1973 ),
Microthyriales ( Arnaud 1918 )
,
Dothideales
(M̧ller & von Arx 1962 ) and,
Melanommatales ( Barr 1987 )
. In addition,
Kirk et al . (2008)
annotated this family in
Microthyriales
and Lumbsch & Huhndorf (2010) placed
Microthyriaceae
in
Dothideomycetes
families incertae cedis . However, most of those studies have suffered from phenotypic plasticity, which has led to misinterpretations and subjected to various taxonomic confusions as many species are known only from their morphological characteristics ( Doidge 1942 , M̧ller & von Arx 1962 , Luttrell 1973 , Barr 1987 , Hofmann 2010 ). But, in the last two decades morphology combined with molecular data has emerged as the primary research tool for
Microthyriaceae
species identification, thus taxonomic placements of this family have made significant progress. For example, the findings of
Wu et al . (2011)
, which provided a broad revision of
Microthyriaceae
based on morphology and molecular data, helped to clear up a lot of ambiguities in the family.
Wu et al . (2011)
findings have been followed by numerous subsequent studies, most of which have used multi-gene phylogeny for their phylogeny analyses (
Hongsanan et al . 2014
,
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). Recent investigations have identified a number of new genera in
Microthyriaceae
, thus this family is currently phylogenetically highly diversified. For example,
Qiao et al . (2021)
introduced two aquatic hyphomycetes genera (
Antidactylaria
and
Isthmomyces
) from China and
Nothoanungitopsis
by
Crous et al . (2021)
from South Africa . In addition,
Zheng et al . (2022)
introduced another two aquatic hyphomycetes genera from China (
Keqinzhangia
and
Pseudocoronospora
) based on morphology and phylogeny evidence.

Tropical, subtropical, and temperate climates all include a variety of
Microthyriaceae
species (M̧ller & von Arx 1962 , Luttrell 1973 , Barr 1987 ,
Wu et al . 2011
,
Hongsanan et al . 2020
,
Qiao et al . 2021
,
Zheng et al . 2022
). However, despite the fact that
Microthyriaceae
species have been found all over the world, most of them lack DNA molecular data. For instance, only five
Microthyrium species
have molecular data, out of the 91
Microthyrium species
listed in Index Fungorum (2022) . In addition, DNA molecular data not available for some genera, such as
Arnaudiella
,
Calothyriopsis
and
Seynesiella (
Hongsanan et al . 2020
)
. Therefore, it is vital to gather representative species of these genera and collect DNA data to clarify their phylogenetic relationships. In this study, we provide taxonomic details for two new species in
Paramicrothyrium
and
Tumidispora
based on both morphology and phylogeny. Both species were collected from dead leaves in Thailand .

In this study,
Paramicrothyrium bambusae
provided a well-supported lineage with
P . chinensis
( FIGURE 1 ). As well as, both have similar morphological characteristics, such as superficial, scattered, flattened, circular, dark brown to black thyriothecia and with an irregular ostioles, without a darkened ring (
Wu et al . 2011
). However, other morphological characteristics could not be compared as they have different morphs.
Paramicrothyrium bambusae
can be distinguished from the type by phylogenetic evidence and their smaller thyriothecia (90–120 × 100–130 μm vs 420–590 μm diam.) (
Wu et al . 2011
). Apart from
P . bambusae
, another new species,
Tumidispora thailandica
is also introduced here with support from both morphology and molecular data. Our phylogeny shows that
T . thailandica
clustered with type (
T . shoreae
) with high statistical support ( FIGURE 1 ). Both have similar morphological characteristics, such as flattened, circular, brown to black thyriothecia with a prominent darkened area around the central ostiole, cylindrical to cylindric-clavate, short pedicellate asci and 1-septate, hyaline ascospores with a swollen apical cell (
Ariyawansa et al . 2015
). Nevertheless,
T . thailandica
can be distinguished from the type by distinct size differences of asci and ascospores. In addition,
T . thailandica
has fusiform, rounded ends ascospores with two appendages in the upper cell, whereas
T . shoreae
has narrowly fusiform ascospores with sub-papillate ends and lacking of appendages (
Ariyawansa et al . 2015
). However, for the expansion of these two genera, additional collections are necessary for future studies.
The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest.

The authors thank Shaun Pennycook for nomenclatural advice. This research was partially supported by the Chiang Mai University, Thailand . The research was supported by Post-Doctoral Fellowship 2022 for Reinventing Chiang Mai University (Grant No. R000030885). This project was also funded by the National Research Council of Thailand (NRCT) N42 A 650198.
